description: Ratios (p-1)/d, where p is a prime and d is the number of digits of the periodic part of the decimal expansion of 1/p.
comments: The sequence of 2nd, 4th and following terms coincides with A006556, which gives the "number of different cycles of digits in the decimal expansions of 1/p, 2/p, ..., (p-1)/p where p = n-th prime different from 2 or 5".
links: Carmine Suriano and T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 101 terms from Carmine Suriano)
formula: a(n) = (b(n)-1)/c(n), where b(n) and c(n) are the n-th terms of A000040 and A048595 respectively.
example: a(13) = 40/5 = 8, since 41 is the 13th prime and the periodic part of 1/41 = 0.02439024390... consists of 5 digits.
mathematica: Join[{1, 2, 4}, Table[p = Prime[n]; (p - 1)/Length[RealDigits[1/p, 10][[1, 1]]], {n, 4, 100}]] (* _T. D. Noe_, Oct 04 2012 *)
author: _Klaus Brockhaus_, Apr 01 2001
